fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:fullName: ISO/IEC 10918-1:1994. Information technology -- Digital compression and coding of continuous-tone still images, progressive DCT-based (formal name); Progressive JPEG (common name)
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:description: Lossy compression encoding for full color and grayscale continuous-tone images that employs discrete cosine transforms (DCT) and other processes, and encodes similar-positioned coefficients of all 8-by-8-pixel Minimum Coded Unit (MCU) blocks in one action, followed by the next positioned coefficients of all blocks, etc. When a progressive image is decoded, "every other line" appears, displaying a top-to-bottom image relatively quickly; following this, the missing lines are filled in. The encoding and related matters are well described in the ISO specification and on Web sites like those cited in Useful references in this description.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: Lossy compression algorithm for full color and grayscale continuous-tone images that employs discrete cosine transforms (DCT) and other processes, and encodes similar-positioned coefficients of all blocks in one action, followed by the next positioned coefficients of all blocks, etc.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: May be applied in initial-state picture creation; often used for middle- and final-state archiving or end-user delivery.

fdd:relatedTo.fdd:titleName: JFIF JPEG File Interchange Format, Version 1.02

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: JFIF File Interchange Format, Versions 1.00 and 1.01, not described at this Web site at this time

fdd:relatedTo.fdd:titleName: SPIFF Still Picture Interchange File Format

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: JTIF File Format, a variant of TIFF, not described at this Web site at this time

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: Fully disclosed. Developed by the Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG), formally known as ISO/IEC JTC 1/SC 29/WG 10.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: ISO/IEC 10918-1:1994, Information technology -- Digital compression and coding of continuous-tone still images: Requirements and guidelines. Same as ITU-T Rec. T.81:1992.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: Depends upon algorithms and tools to read; will require sophistication to build tools.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:selfDocumentation: See the file format descriptions for JFIF_1_02, SPIFF, and JPEG_EXIF.

fdd:stillImageQF.fdd:clarity: Good, considering that the source data is limited to 8-bits-per-channel. Quality varies according to the sophistication of the encoding and the degree of compression applied. Most commentators agree that, at the same compression ratios, discrete cosine tranforms (DCT) produce less clarity than discrete wavelet tranforms (DWT), used by J2K (JPEG 2000) and other compression algorithms.
fdd:stillImageQF.fdd:colorMaint: See the file format descriptions for JFIF_1_02, SPIFF, and JPEG_EXIF.
fdd:stillImageQF.fdd:beyondImage: Not investigated for this format description.

fdd:magicNumbers.fdd:note: Start of Image (SOI) marker; see also JPEG

fdd:other.fdd:tag: Indicator for profile, level, version, etc.

fdd:values.fdd:note: Start of Frame (SOF) marker for progressive DCT; see also JPEG

fdd:citation.fdd:specReference: ISO/IEC 10918-1:1994. Information technology -- Digital compression and coding of continuous-tone still images: Requirements and guidelines
ITU-T Rec. T.81:1992. Information technology – Digital compression and coding of continuous-tone still images: Requirements and guidelines (same as ISO/IEC 10918-1)

fdd:urlReference.tag: Image Optimization, Part 4: Progressive JPEG…Hot or Not?
fdd:urlReference.comment: 2008 blog by Stoyan Stefanov, compares progressive and baseline. (Blog was no longer available when checked in July 2021.)
